facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 969 of 1963 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 969 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the award dated

facts.text: Appeal against award dated November 13, 1959 of Industrial Tribunal, Assam.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated November 13, 1959 of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam in Sub-References Nos. 25 to 39, 41, 43 to 45, 47 to 51, 54 to 57, 59 to 61, 63 to 67, 69 to 73, 76 and 91 of 1957 and 15 of 1958.

facts.text: Award published in Assam Gazette dated January 13, 1960 via notification December 29, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought, by special leave,. against the award of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam, published in Assam Gazette dated January 13, 1960, vide Assam Government Notification No. 361/55/690 dated December 29, 1959, in References Nos. 25 to 39, 41, 43 to 45, 47 to 51, 54 to 57, 59 to 61, 63 to 67, 69 to 73, 76 and 91 of 1957 and 15 of 1958.

facts.text: Tea industry in Cachar district of Assam subject to economic crisis from June 1951 to March 1953.

anchor.surface_text: During the period from June, 1951 to March, 1953 the entire tea industry in the Cachar district of Assam was subject to an unusual economic crisis. There was a steep rise in the companyt of production due to increase of wages and introduction of subsidised rations.

facts.text: Steep rise in cost of production due to increase of wages and introduction of subsidised rations.

anchor.surface_text: There was a steep rise in the companyt of production due to increase of wages and introduction of subsidised rations. In October, 1949, a Tripartite Conference was held at Silchar and it was decided in this Conference that nearly 20 Tea Estates had become uneconomic and should be allowed to companyvert food companycessions into cash at the rate of 0-4-6 per 34 6 head per day.

facts.text: Tripartite Conference held at Silchar in October 1949 decided nearly 20 Tea Estates uneconomic and allowed conversion of food concessions to cash at 0-4-6 per head per day.

anchor.surface_text: In October, 1949, a Tripartite Conference was held at Silchar and it was decided in this Conference that nearly 20 Tea Estates had become uneconomic and should be allowed to companyvert food companycessions into cash at the rate of 0-4-6 per 34 6 head per day. The need for re-adjustment of labour force was also recognised in this Conference.

facts.text: Ad hoc Committee appointed on February 12, 1949, submitted report on September 13, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The financial position of the Tea Estates however companytinued to cause anxiety to the Government. On February 12, 1949, an Ad hoc Committee was appointed which submitted its report on September 13, 1950.

facts.text: Cachar Plantation Committee constituted on April 4, 1950, report submitted on January 4, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the critical companydition of the tea industry in Cachar another Committee named as The Cachar Plantation Committee was companystituted on April 4, 1.950. The report of the Committee was submitted on January 4, 1951.

facts.text: Sudden recession in world price of tea in 1951, fluctuations from mid June 1951, rapid decline November 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1 951 there was a sudden recession in the world price of tea. Fluctuations companymenced in the middle of June, 1 951 and there was a rather rapid decline in prices of tea in November, 1951.

facts.text: Notification under Minimum Wages Act dated March 11, 1952 raising wages substantially.

anchor.surface_text: To add to the difficulties of the tea industry there was a numberification under the Minimum Wages Act dated March 11, 1952 raising wages of labour substantially.

facts.text: By January 22, 1953, 82 out of 111 gardens in Cachar district had closed down.

anchor.surface_text: Before the team companycluded its investigation the situation had taken a critical turn and the tea industry in Cachar was on the verge of a total companylapse. By January 22, 1953, 82 out of Ill gardens in Cachar district had closed down.

facts.text: Revised notification under Minimum Wages Act dated February 9, 1953 for Cachar tea estates suspending food concessions and raising dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance, of the recommendation of the Committee there was a revised numberi- fication dated February 9, 1953, under the Minimum Wages Act with regard to all the tea estates in the district of Cachar and the uneconomic tea estates in the Assam Valley.

facts.text: After revised notification, economic condition improved, many tea estates refunctioned, retrenched workmen taken back or provided alternative employment.

anchor.surface_text: After the issue of the revised numberification the economic companydition of the tea estates improved and many tea estates started refunctioning. Many of the workmen who were retrenched were taken back in employment and others were provided alternative employment in tea estates outside Cachar district in the Assam Valley district or elsewhere.

facts.text: Union claimed no genuine crisis, financial crisis manipulated by management to revise Minimum Wages notification and crush union.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the Cachar Chah Sramik Union  hereinafter called -the Union  before the Industrial Tribunal was that there was numbergenuine crisis which companyld justify retrenchment, lay off or even reduction of working days in a week.

facts.text: Management contended real sudden financial crisis compelled reduction of working days and retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: The opposite view was put forward by the management and it was companytended on its behalf that it was companypelled to reduce the number of working days and, in some cases, to resort to retrenchment because there was a real and sudden financial crisis in the industry

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal held financial crisis genuine, not manipulated, management entitled to lay off under cl. 8(a)(i) and (iii) and retrench under cl. 9.

anchor.surface_text: Upon these rival companytentions the Industrial Tribunal held, in the first place, that the financial crisis was genuine and was number a result of any manipulation and that the management was entitled under cl. 8 a  i  and  iii  of the Standing Orders to lay off the workmen for an indefinite period.

facts.text: Tribunal awarded compensation at one week's pay for every four months of unemployment, considering amenities as equivalent.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal further held that the management was also entitled to retrench workmen under cl. 9 of the Standing Orders. The Tribunal companysidered that even if the lay off and retrenchment were bona fide and justified, the workmen were entitled to a reasonable companypensation and fixed the quantum of companypensation at the rate of one weeks pay for every four months of unemployment.

facts.text: Supreme Court held lay off justified under cl. 8(a)(i) and (iii) due to sudden slump beyond control.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has also found that the economic crisis of the tea industry in Cachar region was real and was caused by reasons beyond the companytrol of the management of the tea estates. In our opinion, the last part of cl. 8 a  i  which refers to other causes beyond his companytrol would companyer a case of sudden slump in the world market and the companysequent financial difficulties of the tea estates.

facts.text: No victimisation or unfair labour practice in closing gardens or retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has found that there was numbervictimisation or unfair labour practice or mala fide on the part of the management in closing the gardens or in making the retrench- ment.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed we hold that there is numbermerit in this appeal which is accordingly dismissed.

Appeal by special leave from the award dated November 13, 1959 of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam in Sub-References Nos. 25 to 39, 41, 43 to 45, 47 to 51, 54 to 57, 59 to 61, 63 to 67, 69 to 73, 76 and 91 of 1957 and 15 of 1958.

This appeal is brought, by special leave,. against the award of the Industrial Tribunal, Assam, published in Assam Gazette dated January 13, 1960, vide Assam Government Notification No. 361/55/690 dated December 29, 1959, in References Nos. 25 to 39, 41, 43 to 45, 47 to 51, 54 to 57, 59 to 61, 63 to 67, 69 to 73, 76 and 91 of 1957 and 15 of 1958.

To add to the difficulties of the tea industry there was a notification under the Minimum Wages Act dated March 11, 1952 raising wages of labour substantially. A representation was made to the Government of India by Associations of Tea Producers in March and April, 1952 regarding the difficulties of the industry as a result of the steep fall in prices.

holdings.text: The lay off in the present case was justified by cl. 8(a)(i) and (iii) of the Standing Orders

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the last part of cl. 8 a i which refers to other causes beyond his control would cover a case of sudden slump in the world market and the consequent financial difficulties of the tea estates. We accordingly hold that the lay off

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal found crisis real and beyond control; sudden slump in tea prices covered by 'other causes beyond his control' in cl. 8(a)(i); distinguished Dewan Tea Estate case where no sudden slump

holdings.text: The management had the power of retrenching workmen under cl. 9 of the Standing Orders

anchor.surface_text: As regards retrenchment, we are satisfied that the management had also the additional power of retrenching workmen under cl. 9 of the Standing Orders which reads as follows

holdings.reasoning_summary: Satisfied that cl. 9 permits retrenchment with notice or pay in lieu; additional to lay-off power

holdings.text: There was no victimisation or unfair labour practice or mala fide on the part of the management in closing the gardens or in making the retrenchment

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has found that there was no victimisation or unfair labour practice or mala fide on the part of the management in closing the gardens or in making the retrenchment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted Tribunal's finding; not challenged by petitioner

holdings.text: The principle of payment of compensation on retrenchment embodied in s. 25F applied even before Chapter VA came into force, but quantum is discretionary considering relevant factors

anchor.surface_text: There is substance in the argument put forward on behalf of the appellant and the Tribunal has also applied this principle in granting compensation to the retrenched workmen even though the case was not attracted by s. 25F

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature recognised pre-existing practice by Tribunals; cited Indian Hume Pipe; no uniformity pre-statute, Tribunals exercised discretion on factors

holdings.text: One week's wages for every four months of unemployment was adequate compensation; value of amenities like khet land, housing, medical facilities roughly equal to one week's wages

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal has estimated the amount of compensation as one weeks wages for every four months of unemployment and it is not shown on behalf of the appellant that in making this estimate the Tribunal has committed any error

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quantum within Tribunal's discretion; no error of law shown; amenities equated to wage value

holdings.text: Ex gratia payments to workmen on short hours were sufficient compensation as they were in several cases in excess of total loss of wages

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal having examined the entire evidence reached the conclusion that the ex gratia payment was in several cases in excess of total loss of remuneration on account of the notification under the Minimum Wages Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal reviewed evidence; payments often exceeded loss; short hours even in normal times

holdings.text: There is no merit in this appeal which is accordingly dismissed

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed we hold that there is no merit in this appeal which is accordingly dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All arguments rejected; Tribunal award upheld

precedents.cited_proposition: financial difficulty from stoppage of bank finance does not fall under 'stoppage of power or supply' or 'other causes beyond his control' in cl. 8(a)(i) of Standing Orders without evidence of being beyond control
precedents.cited_holding: the stoppage of financial assistance will number fall within the phrase stoppage of power or supply in cl. 8 a i of the Standing Orders. It was also pointed out in that case that there was numberevidence produced on behalf of the management to substantiate its plea of number-availability of finance

precedents.case_name: Workmen of Dewan Tea Estate v. Their Management
precedents.cited_proposition: in that case there was no sudden slump in tea prices but difficulty in obtaining financial facilities from banks and it was an individual case of management financial difficulty
precedents.cited_holding: there was numbersudden slump in the price of tea but there was difficulty experienced by the management in obtaining financial facilities from banks

precedents.cited_proposition: by enacting Ch. VA the legislature was merely recognising the practice of payment of compensation by Labour Tribunals before the date of the amendment and standardised it

precedents.citation: The Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen, and another 1

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen, and another 1

precedents.case_name: Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Industrial Tribunals had been awarding compensation even before s. 25F but there was no uniformity and Tribunals considered variety of factors exercising complete discretion
precedents.cited_holding: Industrial Tribunals had been awarding compensation even before the enactment of s. 25F but there was no uniformity or certainty in the matter and in determining the amount of compensation the Tribunals considered a variety of relevant factors
